Peroxomolybdate supported on water soluble polymers as efficient catalysts for green and selective sulfoxidation in aqueous medium Jeena Jyoti Boruah 1 Kabirun Ahmed 1 Srewashi Das Sandhya Rani Gogoi Gangutri Saikia Mitu Sharma Nashreen S. Islam ⁎ Department of Chemical Sciences, Tezpur University, Napaam, Tezpur 784028, Assam, India Department of Chemical Sciences Tezpur University Napaam Tezpur Assam 784028 India ⁎ Corresponding author at: Dept. of Chemical Sciences, Tezpur University, Napaam, Tezpur-784028, Assam, India. Tel.: +91 3712267007 (O)/+91 9435380222 (Off.); fax: +91 3712267006. 1 These authors contributed equally to this work. Graphical abstract Highly efficient recyclable and eco-compatible catalysts comprising peroxomolybdate immobilized on water soluble polymers have been developed for green and chemoselective oxidation of sulfides to sulfoxides in aqueous medium. Peroxomolybdenum(VI) species immobilized on linear water soluble polymers formulated as, [MoO(O2)2(sulfonate)]–PS [PS =poly(sodium vinyl sulfonate)] (PSMo) and[Mo2O2(O2)4(carboxylate)]–PA [PA =poly(sodium acrylate)](PAMo) served as efficient and recyclable catalysts for selective oxidation of organic sulfides to sulfoxide in water with 30% H2O2. The new polymer anchored complex, PSMo has been prepared by reacting H2MoO4 and 30% H2O2 with macromolecular ligand, poly(sodium vinyl sulfonate) and characterized by elemental analysis, spectral studies (FTIR, Raman, 13C NMR, 95Mo NMR, UV–vis), SEM, EDX and TGA-DTG analysis. The catalytic protocol effects clean and facile oxidation of a wide range of sulfides to afford pure sulfoxides with high TOF and excellent chemoselectivity at ambient temperature,with an easy work-up procedure. The catalysts can be regenerated in-situ and recycled at least up to ten consecutive reaction cycles without significant loss of activity and are amenable for ready scalability. The catalytic procedure thus provides an ecologically sustainable alternative as it involves water as solvent, H2O2 as green oxidant, a recyclable non-polluting catalyst, and is absolutely free from halide, organic co-solvent or co-catalyst. This is the first catalytic protocol for selective aqueous oxidation of sulfides using a catalytic system based on peroxometal species supported on water soluble polymers. Keywords Peroxomolybdenum(VI) catalyst Water soluble polymers Chemoselective sulfoxidation Non-polluting oxidation catalyst Selective aqueous sulfoxidation 1 Introduction Selective oxidation of organic sulfur containing compounds to sulfoxides is one of the pivotal reactions in organic synthesis, which holds immense interest from both chemical as well as biological perspectives [1–9]. Sulfoxides and sulfones serve as versatile synthetic precursors for production of a range of fine chemicals and biologically active molecules including pharmaceuticals, agrochemicals and chiral auxiliaries [4–9]. In addition, oxidative desulfurization of crude oil based on sulfide oxidation, is emerging as a sustainable alternative to the traditional catalytic hydrodesulfurization process [10–14]. Currently, with the ever increasing environmental concerns, research efforts are being oriented to development of simple, atom economical catalytic oxidation processes that use safer green reagents and oxidants, as well as benign non-polluting reaction media [15–32]. Among the multitude of available organic oxidants, aqueous 30% H2O2 with its high oxygen content, has been identified as an ideal atom efficient and environmentally acceptable terminal oxidant [13–16,27–30]. Consequently, scores of promising methodologies for selective sulfide oxidation with H2O2 using both homogeneous and heterogeneous transition metal catalysts have been reported in recent years [13–19,32–46]. Nevertheless, there still remains plenty of opportunities to design new alternative catalysts which can perform optimally in safer reaction media under mild condition, as some of the available protocols still rely upon volatile and toxic organic solvents, or require harsh reaction conditions, long reaction time, a promoter or a co-catalyst, or suffer from poor recyclability, which might compromise the ecological sustainability of an otherwise efficient process. Water is indeed the ultimate green natural solvent, being inexpensive, non-toxic, readily available with great redox stability and heat capacity [47–53]. It is therefore not surprising that we have been witnessing a dramatic upsurge in interest on water based organic synthesis [15,18,22,36,49–58]. Concomitant with the growing importance of aqueous phase organic reactions, the development of water-tolerant catalysts and water soluble ligands to support such transformations has become an area of intense investigation [50–52]. We have reported in recent years, several new catalysts and eco-compatible synthetic methodologies involving polymer immobilized peroxo derivatives of vanadium [59], molybdenum [17,42] and tungsten [20,42] for oxidative transformations, such as sulfide oxidation and oxidative bromination, using aqueous H2O2. Significantly, a set of peroxoniobium complexes has been shown to be excellent recoverable catalysts for clean conversion of organic sulfides with 30% H2O2 to the corresponding sulfoxide or sulfone with high selectivity and functional group compatibility in water [18]. In continuation of our efforts to develop simple and sustainable routes to accomplish selective sulfoxidation in aqueous medium, in the present work we have attempted to explore the scope of generating new peroxomolybdenum (pMo) based catalysts using water soluble polymers (WSP) as supports. We have envisaged that the combination of WSP support with a catalytically active pMo species would add advantages of polymeric reagent (stability and phase homogeneity to the catalyst and oxidant, for instance) to the inherent oxidant ability of the pMo species to afford immobilized recoverable catalysts usable in aqueous medium. Previous research has adequately proved that pMo complexes serve as stoichiometric oxidants or catalysts to activate H2O2 in a variety of organic oxidative transformations [17,22,60–65]. Utility of water soluble macromolecular metal complexes in diverse fields including biomedical [66,67] and environmental applications [67–69] has been well-documented in the literature [70]. However, the concept of application of soluble non-cross-linked polymers as support for attaching active metal peroxo complexes in catalyst design appears to have received scant attention, although the use of soluble polymers to recover catalyst in synthetic approaches related to peptide synthesis was introduced by Merrifield and Letsinger in the 1960 [71–73], which paved the way toward developing immobilized homogeneous catalysts [74,75]. It is pertinent to mention that we have previously gained an access to series of well-defined and stable peroxometal containing macro complexes by anchoring peroxo derivatives of vanadium, molybdenum or tungsten to the pendant functional groups of a variety of WSP matrices [59,76,77]. As some of these compounds exhibited unique oxidant activity as well as bio-relevant properties [59,76–78] very distinct from the corresponding neat peroxo complexes, the study of peroxometal anchored soluble macro complexes has subsequently been recognised as a promising new field [34,78]. Herein, we present a new catalytic protocol for H2O2 mediated selective oxidation of thioethers in aqueous medium using diperoxomolybdenum(VI) species anchored to non-cross linked soluble polymer resins, poly(sodium acrylate) (PA) or poly (sodium vinyl sulfonate) (PS) as recyclable catalysts. For practical application of the water soluble macroligand, apart from high hydrophilicity it should ideally possess an adequate molecular weight distribution, easy and cost-effective route of preparation, chemical stability, and high affinity to bind metal ions [79,80]. Apart from fulfilling all these requirements the chosen polymer supports are biocompatible and non-toxic as evident from their extensive use in development of pharmaceutical formulations [80]. As far as we are aware, this is the first report on application of a peroxometal derivative supported on water soluble polymer as catalyst for sulfide oxidation. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Catalyst preparation and characterization Preparation of polymer anchored metal complexes using soluble polymeric ligands, which are essentially polychelatogens, often offers the convenience of adopting synthetic protocols used for obtaining their monomeric analogues. The new supported oxodiperoxomolybdenum catalyst, PSMo has been prepared conveniently by the reaction of molybdic acid, H2MoO4 with 30% H2O2 using commercially available polymer, poly(sodium vinyl sulfonate) in aqueous medium, as shown in Scheme 1 . The macro complex PAMo has been obtained earlier using an analogous synthetic protocol [76]. The pH of ca. 5 was found to be optimal for the desired synthesis. It was also important to limit the amount of water to that contributed by the hydrogen peroxide and sodium hydroxide solution used. The catalyst was finally isolated as solid by solvent induced precipitation using acetone. The water soluble compound PSMo like the polyacrylate bound catalyst PAMo, remains stable in the solid state for several weeks stored dry in closed containers at ambient temperature. The catalyst PSMo was characterized by elemental analysis and a combination of spectroscopic techniques viz., FTIR, 13C NMR, 95Mo NMR, UV–vis, as well as SEM- EDX and TGA-DTG analysis. The presence of pMo species in the compound in its oxodiperoxo form, [MoO(O2)2] was indicated by elemental analysis data showing the Mo:O2 2− ratio as 1:2. The molybdenum loading on the polymer, estimated on the basis of Mo content obtained from elemental analysis, atomic absorption spectroscopy (AAS) and EDX spectral analysis was found to be 1.02mmolg−1 of the polymeric support [Table S1 (Supplementary information)]. The value is observed to be slightly lower than the metal loading of the catalyst PAMo (1.45mmolg−1 of support). The occurrence of Mo in its +6 oxidation state in the immobilized compound was confirmed by the magnetic susceptibility measurement which revealed the diamagnetic nature of the compound. 2.1.1 SEM and energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) analysis The scanning electron micrograph shows that the smooth and even surface of the pristine polymer after the incorporation of pMo species, undergoes considerable morphological changes in PSMo revealing that the metal ions are distributed across the external surface of the polymer [Fig. 1 (a) and (b)]. Moreover, Energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopic analysis, carried out by focusing multiple regions over the surface of the polymeric catalyst clearly showed the presence of Mo, Na, C, O and S in the compound [Fig. 1(c)]. The composition of the compound as obtained from EDX analysis data was in close agreement with the elemental analysis values [Table S1 (supplementary)]. 2.1.2 IR, Raman and electronic spectral studies The FTIR and Raman spectra of the catalyst PSMo displayed the expected spectral pattern to indicate successful anchoring of pMo species to the polymer chain via pendant sulfonate group. As seen in Fig. 2 , the IR spectrum of the neat poly(sodium vinyl sulfonate) showed the ν sym vibration of sulfonate anion at 1040cm−1 in addition to a strong broad band representing SO stretching at 1190cm−1 [81,82]. The weak intensity ν a sym(CH2) and bending mode of CH2 group of the polymer chain occurred at 2954 and 1446cm−1, respectively [81,83,84]. In the spectrum of PSMo, apart from the band at 1042cm−1, a broad band with a distinct absorptions at 1210 and 1170cm−1 appeared which may be ascribed to the splitting of SO stretching vibrations originating from complexed sulfonate group [81,84–86]. The spectrum also showed diagnostic features depicting the presence of terminal oxo and side-on bound peroxo groups of the [MoO(O2)2] moiety with an intense absorption at 960cm−1 and well resolved bands at 860, 610 and 530cm−1 corresponding to ν(MoO), ν(OO), ν asym(MoO2) and ν sym(MoO2) frequencies, respectively [87,88]. The IR results have been corroborated further by the complementary Raman spectrum (Fig. 3 ) which exhibited the well resolved bands corresponding to ν(MoO), ν(OO), ν asym(MoO2) and ν sym(MoO2) vibrations at 974, 880, 650 and 553cm−1, respectively [89]. It also enabled identification of ν sym(SO) as a sharp absorption at 1080cm−1 as well as a broad band located in the 1150–1290 region with a peak at 1205cm−1 which may be ascribed to complexed sulfonate group [76,77,81,90,91]. The absorptions representing ν a sym(CH2) and shear mode of vibration of CH2 group of the polymer support were observed as strong band at 2956cm−1 and a relatively weaker intensity band at 1492cm−1, respectively [92]. The electronic spectrum of the compound recorded in aqueous solution displayed weak intensity broad band at 310–330nm, which is characteristic of peroxo to metal (LMCT) transition of a diperoxomolybdate species [Fig. S1 (Supplementary information)] [76,93]. 2.1.3 13C and 95Mo NMR The 13C NMR spectrum of the neat poly (sodium vinyl sulfonate) shows characteristic resonances due to the chain carbon atoms of CH2 and CH groups at 30.97 and 54.51ppm, respectively. In the spectrum of PSMo, positions of these peaks showed no significant shift compared to parent polymer, with CH2 and CH signals appearing at 30.98 and 54.53ppm, respectively indicating that the chain carbon atoms remain practically unaffected after incorporation of pMo moieties into the polymer matrix [Fig. S2 (Supplementary information)]. The observation is not unusual [76,77], considering that the metal anchoring occurs via pendant sulfonate groups and hence, are well separated from the carbon atoms of the polymer chain. The 95Mo NMR has been recognised as a sensitive and highly useful technique to study the nature of peroxomolybdenum species in aqueous solution [94]. 95Mo NMR spectrum of PSMo provided an unambiguous evidence in support of the presence of pMo species in its oxodiperoxo form by displaying (Fig. 4 ) a single resonance at −230ppm (relative to [MoO4]2−), as has been observed previously in case of the catalyst PAMo at −225ppm. These signals are in the range expected for a diperoxo molybdenum species [76,89,94]. Identification of a single peak in the spectrum further confirmed the existence of Mo(VI) in the compound in a single co-ordination environment suggesting inter alia, that the compound did not undergo hydrolysis and remained stable in solution. The stability of the catalyst PAMo in aqueous solution has been established previously [76]. 2.1.4 Thermal analysis The TGA-DTG profile of the catalyst, PSMo is shown in Fig. 5 , which revealed that the compound undergoes multistage decomposition on heating up to a final temperature of 750°C. Similar to other pMo compounds immobilized on WSP, including the catalyst PAMo [76], and unlike some monomeric peroxomolybdenum compounds [93], the catalyst PSMo did not explode on heating. After the initial dehydration step occurring with the liberation of water molecules of crystallization in the temperature range of 74–101°C, the next decomposition stage has been observed in the range of 110–199°C, with the corresponding weight loss of 6.04%, due to the loss of peroxo groups from the complex. The absence of peroxide group in the decomposition was also verified by its IR spectrum. The compound subsequently undergoes two decomposition processes accompanied by a weight loss of 43.63% in the temperature range commencing at 379°C which continued up to 750°C. On the basis of the thermal degradation pattern documented for poly(vinyl sulfonate) sodium salt, these decompositions have been ascribed to loss of sulfonate group with concomitant breakup of the polymer matrix [95]. It has been shown previously that the loss of sulfonate group is accompanied by release of ethylene, water, SO2 and CS2 from the compound [95]. The residue remaining at the end of the degradation process of the catalyst was characterized to be a hydrated oxomolybdenum species which showed the typical ν(MoO) and ν(OH) bands in the IR spectrum and was devoid of absorptions attributable to peroxo and the polymeric ligand of the starting catalyst. Significantly, the degradation pattern of PSMo closely resembled the pattern exhibited by the peroxotungsten containing analogue reported previously by us [77]. The TGA-DTG profile of the compound was thus found to be in conformity with the composition and formula assigned to the compounds. On the basis of the above collective evidences, a structure of the type shown in Fig. 6 has been proposed for the catalyst PSMo. 2.2 Catalytic activity of the supported complexes, PSMo and PAMo 2.2.1 Oxidation of sulfides to sulfoxides The macro complexes PSMo and PAMo were examined for their catalytic efficiency in sulfoxidation reaction with 30% H2O2 as terminal oxidant under aqueous conditions. In order to optimize the reaction condition an exploratory experiment has been first conducted employing thioanisole as the representative substrate and PSMo as the catalyst, maintaining Mo: substrate molar ratio at 1: 1000, and under continuous stirring at ambient temperature. The details of the study are summarized in Table 1 . To our pleasure, under these conditions MPS was completely and selectively transformed into sulfoxide within 90min of reaction time with a reasonably good TOF (Table 1, entry 1). Our assessment of the effect of the catalyst amount on the rate and selectivity of the reaction revealed that, increasing the amount of catalyst led to a substantial acceleration of thioanisole oxidation as expected, but rendered a decrease in the resulting TOF (Table 1, entry 3). On the other hand, the catalyst worked well even at Mo: substrate ratio of 1: 2000 with 2 equivalents of H2O2 affording a good TOF, albeit the reaction time increased considerably. Subsequently, the influence of the amount of oxidant on the reaction profile was examined. It was gratifying to note that increase in the amount of the oxidant led to a significant enhancement of the rate of the reaction, enabling us to achieve over eight fold improvement of TOF (Table 1, entry 7) simply by using 4 equivalents of H2O2, without altering other reaction parameters. Thus, for achieving best results in aqueous medium without compromising the selectivity, we have decided to maintain a Mo: substrate molar ratio of 1: 1000 and substrate: H2O2 at 1: 4 for subsequent reactions. A blank experiment conducted in absence of the catalyst under otherwise analogous reaction conditions, showed very low conversion of MPS to sulfoxide (ca. 13%) within the stipulated reaction time, (Table 1, entry 15), confirming the indispensability of the catalyst in obtaining the targeted product at a remarkably faster rate. Furthermore, we have investigated the activity of the supported pMo catalyst vis-à-vis unsupported peroxo molybdate generated in situ, by adding Na2MoO4 to the reaction mixture containing H2O2 under optimized reaction condition, maintaining essentially the same Mo: MPS ratio of 1: 1000. The distinctly superior activity displayed by the supported catalyst relative to the neat pMo species (Table 1, entry 14) made it apparent that immobilization of pMo species on the WSP support indeed led to an enhancement of the catalytic efficiency pMo derivatives both in terms of yield, as well as product selectivity. We have also performed the oxidation reactions under identical condition using the free polymer PA or PS in lieu of the pMo supported catalysts. The yield obtained in each case was nearly the same as that obtained from the blank experiment conducted in absence of the catalyst (Table 1, entry 16). The results clearly demonstrated that the chosen pristine polymers have no observable effect on the course of the oxidation reaction. Next, we considered it imperative to examine the performance of the catalysts in a variety of solvents other than water, since solvents have been known to have immense influence on the activity and selectivity of catalysts in sulfoxidation reaction. The solvent effect has been assessed in the oxidation of methyl phenyl sulfide using a series of common organic solvents viz., methanol, ethanol, acetonitrile, chloroform and dichloromethane. Interestingly, apart from water, the methodology for sulfoxidation has been found to be compatible in presence of other polar protic organic solvents such as methanol and ethanol, although not very effective in non-polar solvents (Table 1, entries 8 and 9). A good conversion was also obtained in acetonitrile although without product selectivity (Table 1, entry 10). It is notable that despite the insolubility of the catalysts in neat organic solvents, in presence of aqueous H2O2 of the reaction mixture, both the catalysts dissolve completely in the water miscible solvents viz., methanol, ethanol and acetonitrile, affording homogeneity of the catalytic process. From our survey of the solvent effect on sulfoxidation, water emerged to be the best solvent as indicated by the maximum TOF obtained along with 100% selectivity with respect to sulfoxide, despite the poor solubility of the organic substrates in water. Such observation is not unusual as it has been amply demonstrated by Sharpless et al. [52], followed by reports from some other laboratories [96,98], that for reactions to occur optimally in neat water, solubility of the organic reagents is not a fundamental requirement. Furthermore, our results are in accord with previous findings which showed that selective oxidation of sulfides to sulfoxides is highly favoured in polar protic solvent with ability to form H-bond [18,19,22,96–98]. It is worthy to note that in the present work all transformations occurred at the natural pH of the reaction medium. Notwithstanding previous literature [99–101], including our own work [18,42] showing considerable improvement of catalytic activity of peroxometallates in oxidative transformations in presence of acidic additives, we refrained from adjusting the pH as we endeavoured to bring about the desired transformations under mild condition, without involving any acid and by avoiding or minimizing the use of other hazardous auxiliaries. Also, in view of the environmentally benign aspect, we have chosen room temperature for our studies although, a significant increase in TOF could be attained at a moderately higher temperature as shown in (Table 1, entry 13). Having established the optimized reaction conditions for selective sulfoxidation of the model substrate, we extended the study to a range of structurally diverse sulfides such as dialkyl, diaryl, aryl alkyl, aryl vinyl, aryl alcohol as well as dibenzothiophene (DBT). The results depicted in Table 2 reveal that excellent yield with complete selectivity could be obtained in presence of each of the catalysts, PSMo and PAMo, across the series of substrates examined, affording the corresponding sulfoxide as the sole product. Significantly, no over oxidation of sulfoxide to sulfone was noted under the investigated conditions. Thus the catalytic protocol, being able to stop the oxidation at the sulfoxide level, provided complete control over degree of oxidation of the substrate. The catalyst PSMo, supported on poly (sodium vinyl sulfonate) with monomeric oxodiperoxomolybdenum moieties was observed to display consistently superior activity compared to the catalyst PAMo having dimeric pMo units. The distinct influence of the co-ordination sphere on catalytic activity of these supported pMo catalysts is thus apparent from the data. The methodology worked well for both aliphatic as well as aromatic substrates, albeit the rates of oxidation showed variations depending on the nature of the substrate and substituents attached. Previous work has already established that sulfide oxidation by H2O2 generally occurs via an electrophilic addition reaction of oxygen atoms, due to which sulfides with higher electron density on sulfur atom are expected to react faster [102,103]. The observed sequence in the present study (Table 2, entries 1–10) indicating the oxidation of aliphatic sulfides to be more facile in comparison to aromatic sulfides as well as other conjugated systems viz., allylic or vinylic sulfides is thus in accord with the decreasing nucleophilicity of the tested substrates, owing to conjugation of sulfur lone pair of electrons of the aromatic and allylic sulfides. It was therefore not surprising that the protocol enabled us to attain the highest TOF value of 11,520h−1 (for PSMo) for dimethyl sulfide oxidation (Table 2, entry 2), whereas the oxidation of diphenyl sulfide and benzyl phenyl sulfides (Table 2, entries 10 and 11) were rather sluggish and DBT being least nucleophilic and a relatively inert refractory sulfide, manifested no sulfoxidation reaction under the optimized condition in water even after 12h of reaction time. Nevertheless, it was possible to selectively oxidize these substrates, even DBT in presence of each of the developed catalysts by replacing H2O with methanol as medium of reaction and using a higher amount of catalyst (Mo: MPS ratio of 1:100). The reaction was conducted at a moderately elevated temperature of 65°C in case of DBT oxidation in order to enhance the reaction rate (Table 2, entry 12). One of the significant attributes of the catalysts is their excellent chemoselectivity displayed exclusively toward sulfur group of substrates containing other oxidation prone functional groups such as allylic, vinylic and alcoholic sulfides. As seen from the data of (Table 2, entries 8 and 9), allylic and vinylic sulfides were chemoselectively oxidized to the corresponding sulfoxide without epoxidation of CC. Similarly, the alcoholic and benzylic sulfides yielded the targeted sulfoxides without affecting any other functional group transformation (Table 2, entries 7 and 11) under the standard reaction conditions testifying to the excellent functional group tolerance of the catalysts. It is important to highlight herein that we have also confirmed the feasibility of the protocol for scaled-up synthetic applications by conducting the oxidation of thioanisole at ten-fold scale under the standard reaction conditions (Table 2, entry 1 e ). Furthermore, the oxidations occurred with high utilization efficiency of hydrogen peroxide (defined as: 100×mol of H2O2 consumed in the formation of the oxidised product/mol of H2O2 converted) [Text S1 (Supplementary information)] [45]. The H2O2 efficiency in the oxidations was found to be in the range of 90–94% in presence of each of the catalysts PSMo and PAMo. The mild reaction condition of the protocol with the requirement of reasonably short reaction time appears to be responsible for the observed high H2O2 efficiency. In case of DBT oxidation, relatively higher reaction temperature employed and longer reaction time required perhaps facilitates direct H2O2 decomposition leading to considerably lower H2O2 efficiency (ca. 58%). It is pertinent to mention that we have also explored the possibility of employing the same catalysts to obtain selectively sulfone from sulfide in aqueous medium, by varying the reaction conditions. Using MPS as the representative substrate, we could finally obtain pure sulfone with 50% H2O2 as oxidant in lieu of 30% H2O2, maintaining substrate: H2O2 molar ratio of 1: 8 and Mo: MPS ratio of 1: 500. The reaction however required nearly 24h for completion and the resulting TOF attained was about 20h−1. On the other hand, when the reaction was conducted in acetonitrile instead of water, MPS was selectively and completely converted to sulfone within 4h, affording a TOF of 253h−1, under otherwise analogous reaction condition. In the non-protic solvent acetonitrile, sulfone formation appears to be relatively more facile probably owing to the inability of acetonitrile to impart stability through hydrogen bond formation to the sulfoxide formed initially from sulfide. In fact, acetonitrile proved to be the best solvent to obtain pure sulfone from sulfide in some previous studies as well [17,21,45,103]. 2.2.2 Recyclability of the catalyst For practical utility of a catalytic process the longevity of the catalyst and its potential for regeneration and reusability are of fundamental importance. Albeit a homogeneous catalyst usually exhibits superior activity and selectivity vis-à-vis its heterogeneous counterpart, its recovery however, often involves tedious separation processes from organic products and lowered activity of recovered catalyst [50,53]. Interestingly however, it has been demonstrated that employing water soluble catalysts and water as the reaction medium it is possible to combine catalytic efficiency with easy recovery of the catalyst through simple phase separation, owing to poor solubility of the organic products in water [50,53]. Recovery of a soluble polymeric catalyst is often achieved by diluting the homogeneous solution with appropriate solvent to induce precipitation of the polymeric species which subsequently enables its isolation from the resulting heterogeneous mixture by filtration or centrifugation [104]. To our satisfaction, in the present study, the catalysts could be effectively regenerated in situ for reuse in subsequent cycles of reaction, simply by H2O2 treatment of the aqueous extract of the spent reaction mixture after separation of the organic product, followed by addition of a fresh batch of substrate after each catalytic cycle. Recycling experiments were conducted under optimized reaction condition using MPS as model substrate. The regenerated catalysts could be reused for at least ten reaction cycles with the activity and selectivity remaining nearly unaltered [Fig. 7 and Table 2 (entry 1 d )]. It was also possible to recover the catalysts as solid by addition of acetone to aqueous extract of the spent reaction mixture after replenishing the peroxide. The recovered catalyst could be reused in subsequent cycles of reaction without further conditioning. The approach of in situ recycling of the catalyst is definitely more convenient as the troublesome separation and purification steps usually associated with soluble catalyst could greatly be avoided. The redundancy of these steps further helped in limiting the use of organic solvents during the process. It is pertinent to mention that, using a similar approach we have previously achieved excellent results in case of recovery of homogeneous peroxoniobium as well as soluble polymer anchored peroxovanadium catalysts used in H2O2 induced oxidations [18,59]. It is important to highlight in this context that the overall TOF of ca. 57,530h−1 obtained using PSMo as catalysts, after ten cycles of MPS sulfoxidation in the present study, is nearly 7 and 4 fold higher than the corresponding values obtained after six reaction cycles in case of our recently reported homogeneous pNb catalysts [18] as well as heterogeneous polymer supported molybdenum(VI) catalysts [17], respectively. Although a direct comparison of the observed results with many of the other available methodologies is difficult in absence of TON or TOF values in most these reports, nevertheless, the efficiency of the catalysts PSMo and PAMo appear to be indeed remarkable, particularly considering the truly mild reaction conditions under which the reactions have been accomplished. In order to further ascertain that the catalysts retain their structural integrity during the catalytic cycles, the regenerated catalysts isolated from spent reaction mixture by treatment with acetone, was dried and subsequently subjected to characterization by elemental and spectral analysis. The FTIR spectra of the recovered catalysts showed the signature peaks corresponding to metal-peroxo as well as pendant functional groups of the polymer support as has been observed in the original catalyst (Fig. 2). The 95Mo NMR spectral pattern of the regenerated catalysts was identical with the corresponding spectrum of fresh catalyst (Fig. 4). Neither the metal loading nor the peroxide content of the recovered catalysts showed any significant decrease compared to the respective starting catalyst as revealed by elemental analysis and EDX spectral data. Moreover, the filtrate obtained after the isolation of the regenerated catalyst, subsequent to completion of the reaction, was treated with a fresh lot of H2O2 and MPS and the reaction was monitored over a period of 1h. The reaction afforded about 12% conversion after stipulated time, which is comparable to the value obtained in absence of the catalyst in the blank experiment. The absence of Mo in the filtrate after isolation of the catalysts was also ascertained by ICP analysis. Results of our studies thus confirm that there was no metal leaching out of the polymer during the catalytic process, indicating that the catalysts are structurally robust being capable of remaining intact during repeated cycles of oxidation. 2.2.3 The proposed catalytic cycle On the basis of the afore mentioned experimental findings, we propose the catalytic cycle for selective oxidation of sulfides to sulfoxide shown in Fig. 8 , using PSMo as representative. The first step of the reaction is likely to be the facile transfer of electrophilic oxygen from the active oxodiperoxomolybdenum(VI) species of the catalyst to sulfide to afford sulfoxide (reaction a) converting itself into a dioxomonoperoxo intermediate. The monoperoxo molybdenum derivative eventually combines with H2O2 and reverts back to form the original catalyst thus completing the catalytic cycle (reaction b). The proposed reaction cycle is in accord with the previous literature [15,17,20,61,64,105,106] on reactivity of pMo and peroxotungsten compounds where the formation of an inactive monoperoxo Mo(VI) and W(IV) intermediate during substrate oxidation by a more reactive diperoxo species of these metals has been well documented. 3 Experimental 3.1 Materials and methods Molybdic acid, poly (sodium vinyl sulfonate) (Mw=4000), methyl phenyl sulfide (MPS), ethyl phenyl sulfide (EPS), dimethyl sulfide (DMS), Methyl p-tolylsulfide (MpTS), dibutylsulfide (DBS), dibenzothiophene (DBT), dihexylsulfide (DHS), phenylvinylsulfide (PVS), 2- (phenylthio)ethanol (PTE), diphenylsulfide (DPS), benzyl phenyl sulfide (BPS) and allyl phenyl sulfide (APS) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich Chemical Company, Milwaukee, USA. Poly (sodium acrylate) (Mw=2100) (Fluka). Hydrogen peroxide and sodium sulfate were obtained from E. Merck, India. Acetone, acetonitrile, methanol, ethylacetate, petroleum ether (boiling range 60–80°C), diethyl ether, dichloromethane, silica gel (60–120mesh), sodium hydroxide are the products of Rankem, India. [Mo2O2(O2)4(carboxylate)]–PA[PA=poly(sodium acrylate)] (PAMo) was obtained according to the method described in our earlier paper [76]. The water used for solution preparation was deionized and distilled. The molybdenum content of the synthesized compounds was determined by atomic absorption spectroscopy (AAS) using Thermo iCE 3000 series atomic absorption spectrophotometer model analyst 200, inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrophotometer (ICP-OES) (Perkin Elmer, OPTIMA 2100 DV) analysis, as well as gravimetrically as molybdenum oxinate [107], MoO2(C9H6ON)2. Elemental analyses for C, H and N was performed on an elemental analyzer (Perkin-Elmer 2400 series II). Peroxide content was estimated volumetrically by procedures described in earlier papers [17,18]. The sodium content was measured by AAS and also with an ionometer (ORION VERSASTER). The IR spectra were recorded by making pressed pellets of samples with KBr using Perkin-Elmer spectrum 100 FTIR spectrophotometer. Raman spectra of the compounds were recorded using a Renishaw InVia Raman microscope equipped with an argon ion laser with an excitation wavelength of 514nm and a laser maximum output power of 20mW. The 13C NMR spectra were recorded on a JEOL JNM-ECS400 spectrometer at a carbon frequency of 100.5MHz, 131072 X-resolution points, number of scans 8000, 1.04s acquisition time, and 2.0s relaxation delay with the 1H NMR decoupling method in D2O. The 95 Mo NMR spectra were recorded in a Bruker AV 400MHz FT-NMR spectrometer at a molybdenum frequency of 26.07MHz with samples in a 10mm spinning tube with a sealed coaxial tube containing D2O, which provided the lock signal. The chemical shift data are recorded as negative values of ppm (δ) in the low-frequency direction with reference to 1M Na2MoO4·2H2O solution at 298K. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out on a SHIMADZU TGA-50 system at a heating rate of 10°Cmin−1 under N2 atmosphere using an aluminium pan. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) characterizations of the compounds were obtained using a JEOL JSM-6390LV Scanning Electron Micrograph attached with an energy-dispersive X-ray detector. Scanning was done in the 10–20μM range, and images were taken at a magnification of 15–20kV. Data were obtained using INCA software. Standardization of the data analysis is an integral part of the SEM-EDX instrument employed. Magnetic susceptibilities of the complexes were measured by the Gouy method, using Hg[Co(NCS)] as the calibrant. 3.2 Synthesis of [MoO(O2)2(sulfonate)]–PS [PS=poly(sodium vinyl sulfonate)] (PSMo) To a solution of molybdic acid (1.84g, 11.50mmol) dissolved in 10mL of 30% H2O2 maintaining the temperature at 30–40°C, 1.5g of poly(sodium vinyl sulfonate) (PS) was added with constant stirring. The resulting mixture was stirred for an hour in an ice bath. The pH of the reaction solution at this stage was recorded to be ca. 2, which was adjusted at 5 by dropwise addition of 8M NaOH solution. On addition of about 50mL of pre-cooled acetone to the reaction solution with constant stirring, a red colored pasty product separated out which on repeated treatment with acetone turned into a microcrystalline solid. The compound was separated by centrifugation, washed 3–4 times with cold acetone and dried in vacuo over concentrated sulfuric acid. The compound was subsequently dried by heating up to 70°C under nitrogen atmosphere. The metal loading calculated from the observed molybdenum content is 1.02mmolg−1 of polymer for [MoO(O2)2(sulfonate)]–PS [Table S1 (Supplementary information)]. FT-IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 1042, 1210, 1170 (SO), 960 (MO), 860 (OO), 610 and 530 (MO2). Raman (cm−1): 1080, 1205 (SO), 974 (MO), 880 (OO), 650 and 553 (MO2). 3.3 General procedure for catalytic oxidation of sulfides to sulfoxides In a typical reaction, organic substrate (5mmol) was added to a solution of catalyst [PAMo (3.44mg) or PSMo (4.9mg), containing 0.005mmol of Mo] and 30% H2O2 (2.26mL, 20mmol) in 5mL of water. The molar ratio of substrate: H2O2 and that of catalyst (Mo): substrate was maintained at 1: 4 and 1: 1000, respectively. The reaction was conducted at room temperature under magnetic stirring. The reaction progress was monitored by thin layer chromatography (TLC) and GC. After completion, the product and unreacted organic substrates were extracted with diethyl ether, dried over anhydrous sodium sulfate and distilled under reduced pressure to remove excess solvent. The crude product obtained was purified by column chromatography on silica gel with ethyl acetate- hexane (1: 9v/v) as the eluent. The product obtained was characterized by a combination of IR, 1H NMR, 13C NMR spectroscopy and melting point determination (for solid products) [Text S2 (Supplementary information)]. 3.4 Procedure for regeneration of the catalyst The recyclability of each of the catalysts was examined by using MPS as the substrate adopting the following procedures. For selective sulfoxidation, the catalyst could be regenerated and recycled in situ. After completion of the reaction run, the aqueous part of the reaction mixture was treated with 30% H2O2 (2.26mL, 20mmol) followed by a fresh batch of substrate and the reaction was conducted under optimized condition in the same manner as reported in the first run (Section 3.5). The progress of the reaction was monitored by thin layer chromatography (TLC) and GC. The process has been repeated for ten cycles of reaction. In an alternative procedure, the recovered catalyst could also be isolated as solid and reused in subsequent cycles of oxidation. The aqueous part of the spent reaction mixture was transferred to a beaker and treated with 30% H2O2 (2.26mL) in order to replenish the peroxide content of the catalyst state. To this solution pre-cooled acetone was added with constant stirring until the solid catalyst separated out which was isolated following the same work up procedure mentioned under Section 3.2. The dried solid catalyst was used in subsequent reaction cycle conducted under optimized condition. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, we successfully developed a simple, cost-effective and environmentally clean catalyst system comprising diperoxo molybdenum moiety immobilized onto non-cross linked water soluble polymer matrices, which exhibited remarkable efficiency in the selective oxidation of organic sulfides to the corresponding sulfoxide with 30% H2O2 in aqueous medium. Compatibility of the catalysts with relatively safer organic solvents such as methanol and ethanol is an additional significant feature of the catalysts, which has been used effectively to obtain high purity sulfoxide from less reactive dibenzothiophene in impressive yield. Most importantly, the catalysts are simply prepared from readily available non-toxic starting materials and are sufficiently robust to afford easy in-situ recyclability for sulfoxidation up to a minimum of ten reaction cycles with consistent activity selectivity profile. Moreover, ease of work-up, excellent chemoselectivity, ready scalability are additional green attributes of this novel methodology making it potentially attractive for practical applications. Our findings thus show that linear soluble polymers can be considered as a green and viable alternative to insoluble cross linked polymer support for designing sustainable peroxometal based catalysts for reactions in aqueous medium. The work on other applications of this highly efficient catalyst system to other important aqueous phase oxidative transformations including oxidation of biomass derived substrates are now underway in our laboratory. coredata.dc:description: Peroxomolybdenum(VI) species immobilized on linear water soluble polymers formulated as, [MoO(O2)2(sulfonate)]–PS [PS =poly(sodium vinyl sulfonate)] (PSMo) and[Mo2O2(O2)4(carboxylate)]–PA [PA =poly(sodium acrylate)](PAMo) served as efficient and recyclable catalysts for selective oxidation of organic sulfides to sulfoxide in water with 30% H2O2. The new polymer anchored complex, PSMo has been prepared by reacting H2MoO4 and 30% H2O2 with macromolecular ligand, poly(sodium vinyl sulfonate) and characterized by elemental analysis, spectral studies (FTIR, Raman, 13C NMR, 95Mo NMR, UV–vis), SEM, EDX and TGA-DTG analysis. The catalytic protocol effects clean and facile oxidation of a wide range of sulfides to afford pure sulfoxides with high TOF and excellent chemoselectivity at ambient temperature,with an easy work-up procedure. The catalysts can be regenerated in-situ and recycled at least up to ten consecutive reaction cycles without significant loss of activity and are amenable for ready scalability. The catalytic procedure thus provides an ecologically sustainable alternative as it involves water as solvent, H2O2 as green oxidant, a recyclable non-polluting catalyst, and is absolutely free from halide, organic co-solvent or co-catalyst. This is the first catalytic protocol for selective aqueous oxidation of sulfides using a catalytic system based on peroxometal species supported on water soluble polymers.
coredata.dc:title: Peroxomolybdate supported on water soluble polymers as efficient catalysts for green and selective sulfoxidation in aqueous medium
coredata.prism:publicationName: Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical
